message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and diagnostic test results suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The most appropriate initial treatment is heparin, followed by bridge to warfarin to prevent further clot formation. Tissue plasminogen activator is reserved for severe cases like massive pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and diagnosis suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The most appropriate course of treatment is to initiate heparin to prevent thrombus growth and to then bridge to warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. Tissue plasminogen activator is not appropriate for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis, which can cause pulmonary embolism if untreated. The most appropriate course of action is to initiate heparin followed by bridge to warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. Tissue plasminogen activator is not appropriate for this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The most appropriate initial treatment for DVT is heparin followed by bridge to warfarin. Warfarin alone may not be effective in the early stage, and tissue plasminogen activator is only used in severe cases where there is a risk of pulmonary embolism or limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and the most appropriate course of treatment for DVT is initiation of heparin followed by bridging to warfarin. Tissue plasminogen activator is used for pulmonary embolism or massive DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and the most appropriate initial treatment is heparin followed by a bridge to warfarin. Tissue plasminogen activator is not the first line treatment for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Heparin is the initial treatment for DVT, followed by a bridge to warfarin. Tissue plasminogen activator is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of deep vein thrombosis and Doppler ultrasonography confirms a large clot in a deep vein. The most appropriate course of action is to initiate heparin and follow with a bridge to warfarin. Tissue plasminogen activator is not the first-line treatment for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is confirmed by Doppler ultrasonography. The most appropriate course of action is to initiate treatment with heparin, followed by a bridge to warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. Tissue plasminogen activator is not used as a first-line treatment for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Heparin is the standard anticoagulant treatment for DVT, and patients are usually bridged to warfarin for long-term treatment. Treatment with tissue plasminogen activator is reserved for cases with a high risk of pulmonary embolism or massive DVT. Thus, the most appropriate course of action is initiation of heparin followed by bridge to warfarin.
